title: Postcard from Hudson-Meng Paleoindian Bison Kill excavation site

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Larry Agenbroad

title: Letter from Larry Agenbroad to Donald Crabtree
creator: Agenbroad, Larry
description: Typewritten letter from Larry Agenbroad. Agenbroad wrote back to Crabtree to give him the best dates to visit the site and tell him that they are welcome to stay with him. There is also a handsketched map of the excavation site with directions on how to access it from town.

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Larry Agenbroad
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Crabtree to Agenbroad where he finalized their plans to visit the Hudson-Meng excavation site. He said that he was hopeful to see Marie Wormington and Vance Haynes.
subject: personal correspondence; excavation (sites); typewritten

title: Letter from Larry Agenbroad to Donald Crabtree
creator: Agenbroad, Larry
description: Handwritten letter where Larry wrote back to Crabtree expressing his happiness that Crabtree was coming on at his planned time. He insisted that Don and Evelyn would eat with his family and see Wormington, Shutler, and Haynes.
subject: personal correspondence; excavation (sites); handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: “Great Persons” Program invitation from Larry Agenbroad
creator: Agenbroad, Larry
description: Typewritten letter where Agenbroad reached out to Crabtree to invite him to be a participant in the “Great Persons” Program sponsored by the Mari Sandoz Society. He also informs Crabtree of his family’s health and asked if the Explorer’s Club had gotten back to him yet or not.
subject: professional correspondence; Mari Sandoz Society; typewritten; Explorer's Club
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter to Larry Agenbroad from Donald and Evelyn Crabtree
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter where Crabtree wrote to Agenbroad to inform him he received the paycheck from the University for the excavation site work and detailed a trip he took with Evelyn. He talked about the Explorer’s Club and attached his qualifications. He then discussed receiving some photos from Junius Bird and Earl Swanson being back in his former position. He also said he met with Francois Bordes and Marie Wormington in Tucson and Denver where they all discussed hammerston vs. billet techniques.
subject: personal correspondence; excavation (sites); typewritten; lithics
associated_names: Wormington, Marie; Haynes, Vance; Gould, Dick
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday letter from the Agenbroads

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Robert Ackerman
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.

title: Possible artifact from mammoth site in Hot Springs, South Dakota

description: Page one: Typewritten letter where Crabtree asked Agenbroad to fill in some notes regarding gravel size and flake position in relation to the skull. Page two: Article that details a piece of fossiliferous flint Larry Agenbroad found associated with a mammoth skull which is hypothesized to provide a clue contemporary existence of man.

creator: Agenbroad, Larry

title: Card from Wanda Agenbroad
creator: Agenbroad, Wanda

title: Holiday card with letter from Wanda Agenbroad

title: Christmas card from Agenbroad family
creator: Agenbroad, Wanda

title: Get well soon card from Larry Agenbroad
creator: Agenbroad, Larry
description: Outside: Art of man in hospital bed with start of joke. Inside: End of joke. Larry wrote on the side that he was happy to visit Don while he was in the hospital and that as soon as he was feeling better he would send him a tool to study.

title: Letter from George Agogino to Earl Swanson
creator: Agogino, George
description: Typewritten letter wherein George Agogino wrote to Earl Swanson to recommend a student to Swanson’s summer program. There is a handwritten note on the bottom of the page reading the name Irvin Rovner, who may be the student in question. There is a note directed to Crabtree at the end saying that Agogino stating the student is a good man and said that he is well advanced in flaking.
subject: personal correspondence; letter of recommendation; field school; typewritten

title: Letter from George Agogino to Donald Crabtree

title: Letter from George Agogino about Evelyn’s illness

description: Typewritten letter where Agogino wrote back to Crabtree that was delighted Crabtree was pleased with Irwin Rovner. He wishes Evelyn well wishes and that everyone is upset about the news of her illness since she is highly respected in the profession. He shares that his mother is hospitalized for the same issue.

title: Letter from Kim Ackerman to Donald Crabtree
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter from Akerman to Crabtree saying that he is currently working on replicating folsom points and a paper on the philosophy of stoneworking.He asked Crabtree for some advice on clamping pieces correctly. Two papers he was involved in are going to be published and he has been elected to the Material Culture Advisory Committee of the Institute for Aboriginal Studies.
subject: personal correspondence; lithics; heat treatment; tool sharing; Folsom points; techniques; handwritten
associated_names: Gould, Dick; Hudson, Tom
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Kim Akerman
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter where Crabtree wrote back to Akerman to inform him that in the last year he had an unspecified amount of surgeries (three of which were done with obsidian blades). He thanked him for the tools Akerman sent him and gave him some advice on controlling his folsom point experiments better. On the back of the letter he adds a PS that Dick Gould is in Cambridge working on a book and is learning from blademakers making gunflints.
subject: personal correspondence; Folsom points; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Gould, Dick
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Kim Akerman
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter where Crabtree wrote to Akerman that his papers were well written and that he hoped to see them in some American journals. He believes Akerman is the only person with any factual knowledge on Aboriginal technologies in Australia and heat treatment. He discussed grinding and edge abrasion prior to flaking and said that he gave Francois Bordes Akerman’s information so he could get in touch when visiting Australia.
subject: personal correspondence; excavation (sites); heat treatment; techniques; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Rovner, Irvin; Crabtree, Evelyn
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Kim Akerman to Donald Crabtree
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter where Akerman wrote to Crabtree about trying to replicate his point work and about some pieces he believed were heat treated. He planned to send Crabtree more examples of what is heat treated and what isn't. Science rejected his papers and asked Crabtree if he could put in a word with Tebiwa and American Antique.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; Tebiwa; handwritten; lithics; tool exchange; techniques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Kim Akerman address change
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter where Akerman sent Crabtree a letter to update him on his new address in North Perth. After his move he is going to go Southeast Kimberley to map sacred areas. He hopes to meet up with Bordes when he returns from SE Kimberley. He asked Crabtree if he got the tape on stone heating and that he hopes to film the process soon.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; film
associated_names: Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Crabtree to praise Kim Akerman’s tape
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.

title: Job and address update from Kim Akerman
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter where Akerman wrote to Crabtree wishing him better health and informing him about his new job, Research Officer for a Land Council, and his new address. He sent a draft of his paper on heat treatment and lithic technology in Western Australia. The envelope has a note that Paul Ossa accepted three of his articles.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; film; envelope; handwritten
associated_names: Ossa, Paul
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Kim Akerman
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Crabtree where he wrote back to Kim congratulating him on his paper on heat treatment of lithic materials in Australia. He compares it to heat treating in the US, but states that the paper is the first factual work on the subject.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; paper; lithics; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Bird, Junius
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Crabtree thanking Akerman
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter where Crabtree thanked Akerman for the blades he had sent and commented on a few pieces being exquisite. He showed his surgeon the heat treated blades, as well as informed Barbara Purdy about them. He sent back some obsidian and described the handheld flaking process.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; tool exchange; surgery; techniques; lithics; typewritten
associated_names: Purdy, Barbara
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Kim Akerman to Donald Crabtree
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter wherein Akerman detailed the wood pressure flake, kangaroo ulna flake, and the kangaroo/wallaby fibula he sent to Crabtree. He then discusses how he started making fluted points, the process with what materials he used and how he achieved the points, then promised to send some of his attempts. He said that on a trip to Peru and Bolivia he collected some crude points and four axe/tomahawk heads.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; fluted points; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter with breakdown of heat treating tape sent by Akerman
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter where Akerman breaks down a tape about heat treating he sent to Crabtree of what is being addressed at what times. At the end of the letter he asks if Tebiwa was interested in publishing his papers.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; film; Tebiwa; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Crabtree about heat treating
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter where Crabtree wrote to Akerman to discuss heat treatment. He had tried to prove it a few years before but was shot down quickly until heat treatment was found in France and Arizona.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Pace, Andy; Longacre, Bill; Ossa, Paul; Norman Tindale
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Akerman to Crabtree regarding his paper
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter wherein Akerman wrote to Crabtree with a copy of his paper and requested any notes Crabtree had. He gives details on the annealing techniques and prestige points. He told Don about a point he found on a hunting trip and how it compares to some others in his personal collection, then detailed two of the points he had sent to Crabtree.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; paper; techniques; tool exchange; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter to Crabtree from Akerman detailing artifacts he had sent
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter from Akerman. He sent Crabtree three artifacts which he gives information on and asks for his comparison. He also asks if Crabtree had any folsom points or clovis work he could send back to him.

source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Kim Akerman to Donald Crabtree
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter from Kim Akerman to Donald Crabtree where he informed him that he was working with some Aboriginal Australians and some nutritionists on an experiment. He also talked about his research on heat treatment and addressed the bone tool that Crabtree had sent him.
subject: professional correspondence; techniques; heat treatment; fluted points; wooden tools; tool exchange; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday card from Bob and Lillian Ackerman
creator: Ackerman, Robert “Bob”; Ackerman, Lillian
description: Front: Print of Porcelain Plate courtesy of Bing and Grøndahl Museum, Copenhagen (Denmark). Inside: “Season’s Greetings written in several languages including English, signed by Bob and Lillian Ackerman. Envelope with stamp cut off.
subject: personal correspondence; holiday card; envelope
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Akerman to Crabtree
creator: Akerman, Kim
description: Handwritten letter wherein Akerman wrote to Crabtree to wish him well on his recovery and shared that the use of stone knives in surgery was occuring with a small population for subincision and circumcision procedures in Australia. He then goes on to discuss his draft on reduction sequences and production of Kimberley points. He’s about ready to write up the heat treatment on stone in the area, and he believes it originated in the south east Kimberleys. He is confused how Native Americans had the practice hundreds of years before it had been recorded in Australia. He also attached a photocopy of a paper he wrote on flaking with wooden tools hoping for input from Crabtree.
subject: personal correspondence; surgery; heat treatment; flaking; techniques; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Terry Alldritt to Donald Crabtree
creator: Alldritt, Terry
description: Handwritten letter from Terry Alldritt. Alldritt wrote to Crabtree to inform him that he was in his last month in Northern Yukon with Bill Irving and their plans for further research. He then asked Crabtree if he could view some of his pressure flaking when he goes to visit his family. He gave his condolences to Crabtree for the death of Earl Swanson.
subject: personal correspondence; excavation (sites); flaking; lithics; handwritten
associated_names: Irving, Bill; Campbell, Steve; Bonnichsen, Rob; Fideli, Frank
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Terry Alldritt to Donald Crabtree
creator: Alldritt, Terry
description: Typewritten letter from Terry Alldritt where he told Crabtree that the student of his that wanted to go to Yukon needed to reach out to Bill Irving. He then talked about personal points in his life.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten
associated_names: Irving, Bill; Saint-Meyrs, Jaque
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from T. C. Allen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Allen, T. C.
description: Typewritten letter from T. C. Allen to Donald Crabtree. They were recommended to Crabtree by Bernice Johnston. The student had collected all kinds of tools from Native American campsites over the years which since sparked an interest. They ask for Crabtree to explain the process since all of their attempts at flaking have been unsuccessful. They asked a handful of other questions about material and marketability before signing off.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten; lithics; flaking; techniques
associated_names: Johnston, Bernice
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Philip Allsworth-Jones to Donald Crabtree
creator: Allsworth-Jones, Philip
description: Handwritten letter from Philip Allsworth-Jones, a student at Cambridge University in Sheffield, England. He writes to praise Crabtree’s work, especially the articles he had published in Tebiwa and Science. He said that the “punch stroke” blade Mr. Fagan returned had since been mislaid. Philip was about to travel to Czechoslovakia for research, and requested examples of punch strike specimens to compare any found to Crabtree’s. He offers to pay for postage, and if not he hopes that Crabtree will at least give him some details on the punch strike method and how it differs from other methods.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; techniques; handwritten; Tebiwa
associated_names: McBurney; Fagan
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Philip Allsworth-Jones
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Crabtree to Allsworth-Jones. He said that Earl Swanson already responded to Allsworth-Jones and he hopes that they have the chance to meet each other soon while Swanson was in London. Crabtree hasn't found a great technique for accurate punch striking, but he said he uses a soft hammerstone and direct percussion to get similar results. He explained why he does this and said he said he would send an article on Corbiac blades to help determine technique. He added that he sent some of his examples to Cambridge University, as well as some made by Francois Bordes and Jacque Tixier.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; techniques; typewritten; health
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Cornwall, Ian; Bordes, Francois; Tixier, Jacques; Crabtree, Evelyn
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Philip Allsworth-Jones to Donald Crabtree
creator: Allsworth-Jones, Philip
description: Seven page handwritten letter from Philip to Don. Allsworth-Jones discussed his move to Czechoslovakia and confirmed that he received the articles that Crabtree had sent him. He discussed some articles and the different types of bulbs they described, ten asked questions regarding different methods of percussion and how they might form the types of bulbs described. He offered to send Crabtree some raw material from Slovakia while he was there.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; techniques; article; handwritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Bradley, Bruce; Misra, V.N; Swanson, Earl; Barnes, Alfred S.; Cheynier, André
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Philip Allsworth-Jones
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter to Philip Allsworth-Jones where Crabtree said that there were more than the three listed methods for bulb types and that he should focus on describing the features rather than categorizing them into such few techniques for his research.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; techniques; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Bordes, Francois; Tixier, Jacques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Philip Allsworth-Jones to Donald Crabtree
creator: Allsworth-Jones, Philip
description: Handwritten letter from Philip Allsworth-Jones to Donald Crabtree to thank Crabtree for answering his previous questions. He was hoping to begin practicing blade making techniques. He mentioned that he would also be attending the Belgrade Conference and he hoped to see Crabtree there. He was hoping to be in Hungary by August.
subject: personal correspondence; techniques; flintknapping; conferences; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Joseph Alsop to Donald Crabtree
creator: Alsop, Joseph
description: Typewritten letter from journalist Joseph Alsop where he wrote to Crabtree in hopes that he could help him find a reference he needed for his book. The book was on art collecting and related actions and was going to be published the next year. He makes a distinction between “treasure gathering” and art collecting. He was hoping Crabtree would recognize what article talked about the milk chocolate flakes from Poland.
subject: professional correspondence; journalism; typewritten
associated_names: Katz
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Joseph Alsop
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Crabtree where he wrote back to Alsop to inform him he wasn't sure of any articles detailing the chocolate colored flint from Poland. He did give him the addresses of Hans Muller-Beck, Jacques Tixier, and Francois Bordes who might have more information on it. He added that he was interested in the title of the book, hoping to read it when it was published.

title: Note of letters of recommendation for James P. Green

title: Fillable Priority Reservation Form from the American Biographical Institute
creator: American Biographical Institute
description: A typewritten letter from the American Biographical Institute to inform Crabtree that the editing of his biographical profile for “Personalities of the West and Midwest” was done. Crabtree was entitled to a pre-publication offer where he could get a plaque, as well reserve copies for himself and others. On the opposite side is a fillable reservation form for copies of the publication and award certificate. There are two envelopes, one addressed to the American Biographical Institute and one addressed to Crabtree. The latter has names, times, and notes that don't seem to have any correlation to the item.
subject: professional correspondence; award; envelope; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Douglas Anderson requesting a letter of recommendation from Crabtree for Richard Gould
creator: Anderson, Douglas; Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Douglas Anderson to Crabtree to request a professional recommendation letter for Richard “Dick” Gould. Gould applied for a senior archaeologist position to be hired at either of Associate or Full Professor level. Included is the job position information. Crabtree responded with his letter of recommendation for Gould and detailed his personal and professional reasons. Anderson wrote back to thank him for the letter of recommendation.
subject: professional correspondence; letter of recommendation; typewritten; job opening
associated_names: Richard Gould; Gould, Dick; Hicks, George L.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Texas Anderson to Donald Crabtree
creator: Anderson, Texas
description: Typewritten letter from Texas Anderson where she wrote to Crabtree to ask which photos of hers that he wanted her to send him. She also noted that it was nice to see him at the SAA meeting. She hoped that Don was well and wanted to know what he was doing.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Texas Anderson to Donald Crabtree
creator: Anderson, Texas
description: Typewritten letter from Texas to Don. She starts by saying attached are copies of the Maya huts, and that in one a a palm frond was being sliced in half with a stake in the ground. She thanked him for the points he had sent her and said she was going to have a necklace designed after one of them. Texas had just finished writing up a report on the Martin Dies site.She scraped her plans to do field work in Belize, and is in the process of submitting her new project proposal to her advisor so she wouldn't have to leave her kids. There is also an envelope from her with four addresses on them: one in Provo, Utah, Rupert, Idaho, Kimberly, Idaho and Flores, Petén, Guatemala.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten; tool exchange; envelope
associated_names: Hall, Grant; Lamb, Tommy; Hole, Frank; Hester, Tom; Shafer, Harry; Hansen, Richard; El Mirador, Proyecto
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday card from Karen and Will Anderson
creator: Anderson, Will; Anderson, Karen
description: Christmas card. Front: Art of Santa Claus in front of a fireplace by Norman Rockwell. Inside: Handwritten letter to Crabtree to apologize for not picking him up at the hospital. They want to make it up to him by inviting him to stay with them in Albuquerque, New Mexico. They request that Donald sends them his address, and they have attached their address and phone number to the bottom. On the other side if the card is the other half of the card and a sign off from Karen and Will.
subject: personal correspondence; health; travel; holiday card
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Richard Anuskiewicz to Donald Crabtree

He sent him photographs of nine chert tools found in Hayward, California asking if he would be able to identify their origin. Crabtree wrote back with some information about the photos and suggested he look into Tebiwa for more information.

Miller from Idaho practicing flintknapping and using the tools they made and is now studying lithic artifacts found on the Sao Paulo shore. He asked that Crabtree send him a reprint of “Experiments in Flintworking.” There is an envelope from Aude to Crabtree attached.

He said he planned to travel around to different areas to gather source material and compare the workability, then he asked for information on how to get ahold of Crabtree's future publications.

title: Letter from Charles J. Bareis to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bareis, Charles J.
description: Typewritten letter from Charles Bareis to Donald Crabtree to inform him on the Illinois Archaeological Survey sponsored workshop on Illinois Archaeology. He said that next years workshop, held on December 4, would have a focus on lithic technology with a focus on chipped stone tools, manufacturing techniques, and ecological adjustments. The members of the Survey extended an invitation for him to attend as the afternoon speaker.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bareis
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Crabtree to Charles Bareis where he thanked him for the consideration to be a speaker but he was unable to commit at that time.He wanted to keep the invitation open as long as he could, and suggested Earl Swanson or one of his graduate students attend in his place. He mentioned the films sold by Idaho State University that better show stone working and have more detail than a demonstration could fill.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten; health
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Crabtree, Evelyn

title: Letter from Charles J. Bareis to Donald Crabtree

description: Typewritten letter from Charles Bareis to Donald Crabtree. Bareis wrote back to Crabtree to give his condolences on Evelyn’s health and that the invitation would remain open. He said the others they considered were Francois Bordes, Jim Fitting (who had already accepted), and was planning to invite Lew Binford in the event that Bordes declines. He discussed the outcome if Crabtree found he couldn't come either before and after acceptance.

He said that they want a live chipping demonstration for his time slot, and that if Crabtree was unable to attend, he asked for a few names he would recommend instead.

He gave information about what he would show and what materials he would be sending.

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bareis

He did arrange for Irwin Rovner to stand in for him if he wasn't able to make it afterall or if it was too much of a hassle to wait for a final answer, and detailed his qualifications and promised that he would be able to do the demonstrations.

creator: Bareis, Charles J.

Bareis said he had assumed that Evelyn’s health had alleviated and that it was definite that Crabtree would attend, however he was fine with letting the invitation stand open. He asked that he inform him if he was unable to make it at least ten days before the workshop, and that Irwin Rovner was fine to fill in under those circumstances. They wanted the chipping demonstration, and hoped the films would only be used as a secondary source if it was integral for the presentation.

He hoped to be there, but in the event he could not, he promised to notify him and Rovner at least two weeks in advance. He planned to send material ahead and asked where the best location to mail it to would be.

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bareis
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bareis. Crabtree wrote to Bareis to inform him he would be able to make it to the workshop, but he would have to bring Evelyn with him. He gave his flight plans and then requested that the date for his hotel reservation be extended forward a day to accommodate the change, as well as a double room for him and Evelyn. He sent ahead the raw materials he would need and attached the freight bill and the completed card for Edward Kalb.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten
associated_names: Kalb, Edward
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Charles J. Bareis to Donald Crabtree with travel expenditure report
creator: Bareis, Charles J.
description: Typewritten letter from Charles Bareis where he thanked Crabtree for confirming that he would be present for the workshop, and made note that he changed the room reservation for him and Evelyn. Arrangements would be made to have the Crabtrees picked up from the airport and he said that Francois Bordes was arriving later that same day. Attached is a travel expenditure report for Crabtree to track his spending for reimbursement after the workshop.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bareis
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree wherein he confirmed the travel plans for the workshop and mentioned that he, Irvin Rovner, and Francois Bordes may possibly all flintknap together during his presentation so more people could see.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Rovner, Irvin
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Charles J. Bareis to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bareis, Charles J.
description: Typewritten letter from Charles Bareis where he thanked Donald for attending the workshop and for his demonstration, and said that his flaking session with Francois was fantastic for everyone. He noted that it was the best workshop they had held yet, and that attendance broke all their records. He thanked him for the obsidian arrowhead Crabtree had made him and for the other material he had left and said that the remaining raw material would be shipped back to him.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; flintknapping; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Charles J. Bareis to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bareis, Charles J.
description: Typewritten correspondence wherein Bareis wrote to Crabtree to thank him for the Christmas card he had sent and to tell him that he would give the left over raw obsidian from the workshop to Irvin Rovner.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten
associated_names: Rovner, Irvin
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Michael Barnes
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten correspondence from Donald Crabtree to Michael Barnes. He gave details on the techniques used to chip a hole into a flake using direct percussion. He also said that the technique is written in more detail in upcoming issues of the Tebiwa journal, which Barnes is subscribed to.
subject: professional correspondence; heat treatment; techniques; stoneworking; Tebiwa; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from James Barr to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barr, James H.
description: Typewritten letter from James Barr. He was doing an excavation in Moosbühl, Switzerland and had found several shattered reindeer mandibles in the working areas. He asked some questions regarding bone working tools and said he was interested in experimenting with them himself in the future.
subject: professional correspondence; bone tools; flaking; techniques; excavation (sites); typewritten
associated_names: Bozinski
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Gerald Bair to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bair, Gerald “Jerry” A.
description: Typewritten letter from Gerald Bair to Donald Crabtree. He is a Ph.D student who was suggested to attend the laboratory training program that summer, and he requested more information on it. He also detailed his issues with his research and with the program he was in.
subject: professional correspondence; field school; typewritten; research
associated_names: Marie; Dr. Turner; Dr. Schoenwetter
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to James Barr
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to inform him on his assumptions about the use of bone and antler tools at the archaeological site. He said that they could have been used as a percussion instrument and given the shattered state they were found in, they likely were. He did say that cores should not get battering marks from tool manufacture, so it would be more likely that they came from functional use. He then suggested that Barr reach out to Hans Muller-Beck and George F. Wili in the area that could help him.
subject: professional correspondence; bone tools; flaking; techniques; excavation (sites); typewritten
associated_names: Muller-Beck, Hans; Wili, George F.; Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from James Barr to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barr, James H.
description: Typewritten letter from James Barr. He wrote to Crabtree to say he was a fan of his work and requested his advice. He was invited to do an advanced study in Switzerland on the raw flint sources used by the Magdalénien hunters at Moosbühl. He wrote to Crabtree to ask if he knew of a successful study involving tracking sources of flint.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; typewritten
associated_names: Bandi
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to James Barr
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Crabtree. He said he did not have any references on being able to track source material from artifacts, and said it was greatly important research that needed to be done. He noted that Robert Heizier and James Griffin had both done some work on the subject and would be able to give him more information, as well as Francois Bordes and Jacques Tixier who might have partial information on the subject.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; typewritten
associated_names: Heizier, Robert; Griffin, James; Bordes, Francois; Tixier, Jacques; Haury; Thompson; Jelinek; Ayres; Longacre
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from James Barr to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barr, James H.
description: Typewritten letter from James Barr. He wrote to Crabtree and thanked him for his encouragement and to inform him that he wrote to Robert Heizier to see if he had any information, but had not heard back yet. He also said that Gary Wright was going to expand his research to include flint, and that he might be of some help.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; typewritten
associated_names: Heizier, Robert; Gary Wright
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday card from Connie and Andy Barron
creator: Barron, Andy; Barron, Connie
description: Holiday card. Outside: Art print of original design No. 142 by Anne Kilham. Inside: handwritten note from Connie and Andy Barron. Andy wrote to thank Crabtree for hosting them when they visited earlier that year, and attached three photos to him of their home in Maine. There is an envelope attached.
subject: personal correspondence; handwritten; holiday card
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Get well soon card from Andy, Mary, and Josh Barron
creator: Barron, Andy; Barron, Mary; Barron, Josh
description: Get well soon card. Front: Photo of a red and black flower with “Get well soon” printed on it. Inside: a note from the Barrons saying they have been meaning to visit Crabtree but haven't had the time. They wish him good health and to recover. There’s a saying printed in the card and it is signed for Andy, Mary, and Josh. Attached is an envelope.
subject: personal correspondence; greeting card; health; envelope
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry where he wrote to Crabtree about the origins of obsidian and tektites. He mentioned Peacock obsidian, found southwest of Guadalajara that acts like tektrite when heated since it melts rather than expands like most obsidians he had experimented with. He wanted to know the results of Crabtree’s studies since he is unable to do the research himself.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; experimental archaeology; heat treatment; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry where he wrote back to ask Barry if he remembered the exact location of the Peacock obsidian. He asked if he would send him some samples to examine and work with.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Ramos, Jorge L.; Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry where he wrote to thank him for telling him where he found the peacock obsidian and he gave him some information on heat treatment and sourcing. He then offered to make some cores and blades for Barry with any material he sent him.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; heat treatment; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Heizier, Robert; Griffin, James; Spence, Michael W.; Dixon, J.E.; Cann, J.R.; Renfrew, Colin
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree. He wrote to say he was preparing for a trip to Central and South America and offered to send the core to Crabtree to Swanson and also said he was excited for the paper Crabtree was going to send him on volcanic glass. He planned to see what artifacts or raw obsidian material would be available in Central and South America and inform Crabtree and offered to send some larger pieces of Peacock cores.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry. He said that he was going to mail Crabtree the core then let him hand it off to Earl Swanson when he was done with it. He told Crabtree to request whatever sized pieces of Peacock obsidian he wanted and he would mail them as soon as Crabtree was back from Washington.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; tool exchange; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree where he wrote back to Ed Barry to answer the questions he had about the tools he had sent him. He mentioned that he was about to start filming The First American and asked if Barry knew where he could source some peacock obsidian and flint in Texas to be sent to the West Coast.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; tool exchange; sourcing; dating; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Eckholm, Gordon; Lanning, Ed
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry where he gave Crabtree vague information on the source site for the peacock Obsidian. He also offered to supply rhyolite and obsidian for the filming of The First American and the exhibit.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; tool exchange; travel; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree where he wrote to Barry about the materials he offered to send, his intentions to create him some artifacts, and when The First American would be airing.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Tixier, Jacques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry where he confirmed that he would send a sample of the material to Crabtree and say that he would show him a spearhead when they had a chance to meet in person. He also asked if there was anyway to purchase copies of Bordes' publications and said that The Gem Center would be featured on an NBC special that fall.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry where he thanked him for the shipment he sent and promised that he would create him an artifact when he could. He mentioned traveling down to El Paso in the winter to meet him and see the artifact then.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; sourcing; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Tixier, Jacques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry where he suggested he try and meet Crabtree in Tucson. He then talked about his own work, the "Cuba situation," and sending him a sample of the Hickoryite.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Medina, Filipe
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry where he discussed how he just returned from his travels and was preparing for flintknapping field school starting in August. He requested raw material: 1,000 pounds of Peacock obsidian sent to Junius Bird at the American Museum of Natural History, 1,000 pounds to be sent to Lucy Lewis at Columbia University, 2,000 pounds, 500 arrow points, and 500 fluted type to be sent to himself in Kimberly. He enclosed a check for the payment and requested that Barry send him larger sizes for his materials and promised him he was going to make him the artifacts he promised him.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; travel; typewritten; field school
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Hanes, Vance; Bird, Junius; Lewis, Lucy
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Gerald Bair
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Gerald Bair to give his condolences for the issues he was having. He said that when he, Bordes, and Tixier visited last year they were incredibly kind. He said that he would not be holding a field school that year, but instead planned to travel for the summer but he would be happy to have him the next year.
subject: personal correspondence; field school; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Tixier, Jacques; Marie
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ed Barry to Donald Crabtree
creator: Barry, Ed
description: Typewritten letter from Ed Barry. He wrote to Crabtree to inform him he mailed out the shipments a few days prior, then assured him he was in no rush to receive the artifacts.
subject: personal correspondence; sourcing; typewritten; travel
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Ed Barry to acknowledge the arrival of the obsidian ordered. He said he was doing research on obsidian from different parts of the world and requested any information from Barry that he could provide in regards to the source of the peacock obsidian. He assured him it wasn't to mine and resell it, but purely for research, and assured confidentiality of the source.
subject: professional correspondence; sourcing; obsidian; dating; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday card from Jane and Jack Bass
creator: Bass, Jack; Bass, Jane
description: Christmas card from Jane and Jack Bass. Front: printed art of some holly and some nuts. Inside: A note from Jane Bass, saying that Quen asked them to send Crabtree some cookies that year. She said that they are grateful for the kindness Crabtree has shown Quen. Underneath their note is a printed Christmas and New Years greeting. Attached is an envelope addressed to Crabtree.
subject: personal correspondence; holiday card; handwritten; envelope
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Quentin Bass to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bass, Quentin
description: Typewritten letter from Quentin Bass to Donald Crabtree where Quentin thanked Crabtree for accepting him to his field school that year. He asked what exactly Crabtree meant in his welcome letter by a collection. He also said that he would bring some Carolina slate, rhyolite, and quartzite.
subject: professional correspondence; field school; typewritten
associated_names: Coe
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin Bass. He thanked Bass for calling around Christmas and detailed new developments in his personal life. He was excited that Bass wanted to continue his studies in lithics and suggested once he was at the University of Utah he could come up to Kimberly on the weekends and work with him.
subject: personal correspondence; typewritten
associated_names: Jennings, Jess; Joffre
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Quentin Bass to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bass, Quentin
description: Typewritten letter from Quentin Bass to Donald Crabtree where he sent him a publication to look at then pass on to a friend. He detailed his progress on stone working and his use of bone tools and heat treatment, then asked Crabtree for his opinion on the Clovis theories. He then requested two letters of recommendations, one to the University of Utah and the other to the University of Tennessee.
subject: personal correspondence; heat treatment; bone tools; Clovis points; letter of recommendation; typewritten
associated_names: Bill; Regensberg, Dick; Willemsen; Mueller-Beck
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin Bass where he said he was happy to hear that he was continuing his studies in lithics. He enclosed copies of his letters of recommendations and said that he selfishly hoped that Bass went to Utah, for both proximity, and to work with Jess Jennings. He was happy that Bass was having success with the Carolina slate and thanked him for the photographs.
subject: personal correspondence; lithics; letter of recommendation; typewritten
associated_names: Jennings, Jess; Bill; Swanson, Earl; Joffre; Sally
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter of recommendation from Donald Crabtree to University of Tennessee for Quentin Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter of recommendation for Quentin Bass written by Donald Crabtree. He suggested Quentin to the program and detailed his skills in flintknapping and his experiments. He discussed what it was like to have Quentin attend his field school.
subject: professional correspondence; letter of recommendation; typewritten
associated_names: Coe, Joffre; Bass, Quentin
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter of recommendation from Donald Crabtree to Jesse Jennings at the University of Utah for Quentin Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter of recommendation for Quentin Bass written by Donald Crabtree. He suggested Quentin to the program and detailed his skills in flintknapping and his experiments and added that he would particularly enjoy having Quentin close in Salt Lake City so they could work together. He discussed what it was like to have Quentin attend his field school and added that if he were to attend University of Utah the three of them could meet often and work together.
subject: professional correspondence; letter of recommendation; typewritten
associated_names: Coe, Joffre; Bass, Quentin
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin and Aleksandra Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin and Aleksandra Bass to thank them for the Christmas gift they sent him. He mentioned wanting to visit them for a vacation later that year, discussed his most recent vacation, then asked Quentin if he decided on a school to attend for his Masters.

associated_names: Tixier, Jacques; Bordes, Francois; Denise Bordes; Ben, Joe; Wheat, Pat; Jelinek, Art

title: Letter from Robert Banta to Donald Crabtree
creator: Banta, Robert
description: Handwritten letter from Robert Banta to Donald Crabtree. He wrote to Crabtree to say that he saw his article in “Fabulous Idaho” magazine and found it interesting. He and other flint knappers who use muzzleloading buffs have been struggling to source flint to work with, and he offers to pay Crabtree $1.50 to $2 a dozen to supply.
subject: personal correspondence; article; handwritten; techniques

title: Holiday card from Quentin and Aleksandra Bass

Handwritten letter from Aleksandra to give Crabtree her and Quentin’s condolences for Evelyn’s passing and to wish him happy holidays. There is an envelope attached.
subject: personal correspondence; holiday card; envelope; handwritten
associated_names: Bass, Quentin

She said he hoped that he was feeling better now than when they last saw him and that she hoped he would come visit them again soon. There is an envelope attached.

source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin and Aleksandra Bass
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Quentin and Aleksandra Bass where he thanked them for their gifts and said that they were very good friends. He apologized for his previously planned trip being cancelled and said that he was anxious to get back to work after his upcoming surgeries. He asked if they would be attending the conference in May in Tucson and said he hoped to attend himself.

subject: personal correspondence; holiday card; envelope; handwritten

title: Holiday card from Quentin and Aleksandra Bass
creator: Bass, Aleksandra; Bass, Quentin

title: Letter from Charles Bechtol to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bechtol, Charles O.
description: Typewritten letter from Charles Bechtol to Donald Crabtree. He wrote to Crabtree to say that he recently got into bow hunting and remembered reading about Ishi, who was able to create an arrowhead from any available materials. He asked if Crabtree could provide him any information on flintknapping and further requested in a few years if he could visit and be taught directly.
subject: professional correspondence; flintknapping; typewritten; stone tools; experimental archaeology
associated_names: Canby, Thomas; Pope, Saxon; Ishi
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bechtol
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Charles Bechtol where he wrote to say that he was unable to reach Bechtol by his business number, but offered to call him on another number and gave him his own. He gave him some suggestions on how to find more information about Ishi's work, but pointed out that there was very little record kept of his work. He then said that Bechtol would likely find use from using obsidian knives in his surgery practice, which he said they could discuss later when they could meet and visit.
subject: professional correspondence; flintknapping; typewritten; stone tools; experimental archaeology; surgery
associated_names: Krober; Gifford; Pope, Saxon; Ishi
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Robert Begole to Donald Crabtree
creator: Begole, Robert S.
description: Typewritten letter from Robert Begole to Donald Crabtree where he wrote to Crabtree to send two different Pacific Coast Archaeological Society Quarterlies with many of his articles he had been reminded to send by George Miller. He then talked on ridge backed tools and said that the closest he knew them to be found were in the Victoria Cave area of South Africa. He then said that Miller hoped that Crabtree would visit to look at the area they were working in.
subject: professional correspondence; stone tools; article; excavation (sites)
associated_names: Miller, George; Childers, Morlin; Davey
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Robert Banta
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Crabtree to Robert Banta. He said between taking care of Evelyn and his work with Idaho State University he had no time to help him. He suggested he write to Abercrombie-Fitch in New York who he had previously sourced his flint from and wished him luck in finding a source.
subject: professional correspondence; health; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Robert Bell to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bell, Robert E.
description: Typewritten letter from Robert Bell to inform Crabtree that Horace G. Loftin was teaching in Panama and wanted someone well versed in lithic technology to go to Panama to teach on it. He gave detailed on what would be paid and who to contact if Crabtree was interested.

title: Letter from Robert Bell to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bell, Robert E.
description: Typewritten letter from Robert Bell to say he saw a copy of the letter Crabtree wrote to Horace Loftin regarding the work in Panama. He said that if Phagan wasn't able to go, Crabtree might be able to later on. He then detailed some information about the excavation site and his travels.

title: Letter from Cyril Belshaw, Editor of Current Anthropology, to Donald Crabtree

She said she was going to bring some blades and core segments from Tula to show everyone.

He said that Bill is the only person who worked with all of the material and knows enough to write a detailed and accurate record. He gave Berg his phone number if he wanted to call and further discuss it.

He asked if Crabtree had a bibliography of recommended readings on the subject. He added that California has many sources of obsidian but the variations and workability was something he didn't fully understand and was hoping that Crabtree could point him in a good direction.

He also offered to loan any artifacts work studying to the Idaho State University Museum.

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Tom Brown

He got to meet Peter White at the Vancouver meetings. He said that Kim Akerman's work would provide invaluable insight to Aboriginal Australians and the tools they used.

title: Letter from Tom Brown to Donald Crabtree
creator: Brown, Tom A.
description: Handwritten letter from Tom Brown to Donald Crabtree where he wrote to tell him that he was returning to Australia and to inform him that he thought the summer session of the flintknapping school was a success. On the next page he is writing while in New York. He thanked him again for all he learned from Crabtree and then detailed his stops in Denver, Chicago, Philadelphia, and New York. He finished his letter by encouraging Crabtree to decide what he wanted to happen to his library after he passed and then have a lawyer handle it.
subject: personal correspondence; lithics; field school; travel; handwritten

title: Note regarding Bonnie Buchanan and Larry Swisher

Underneath that is a note with Larry Swisher's address and something saying that Norman Halvey would be visiting that September.

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Bonnie Buchanan

description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Bonnie Buchanan to inform her on some of his released and upcoming publications on flintknapping that would be beneficial to the production of the First American. He discussed at length the importance of research on lithic technology and to suggest she reach out to Francois Bordes and Jacques Tixier. He also offered his services to demonstrate flintknapping should she want footage of it.

He said he wasn't sure what she had heard regarding Crabtree's surgeries and the tools used for it, but at present the use of stone blades were strictly experimental and academic. He emphasized that it wasn't a practical alternative to use stone tools for cosmetic surgery.

associated_names: Hiro; Jim; Serizawa; Annie
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Holiday postcard from Peter Bleed
creator: Bleed, Peter
description: Holiday postcard. On one side is an art print by Iliana Roels for UNICEF. On the other side it is addressed to Donald Crabtree and a note from Bleed wishing Crabtree the best for the 1980’s.
subject: personal correspondence; holiday card; postcard; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Lou and Sally Binford
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to the Binfords where he wrote to thank them for hosting him and Evelyn while they were visiting and he expressed his excitement to see Lou in Santa Fe. He mentioned that Francois Bordes was planning to visit the United States the next year. He also sent him a random assortment of artifacts with different examples of pressure flaking.
subject: personal correspondence; travel; vacation; tool exchange; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Peter Bleed to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bleed, Peter
description: Handwritten letter from Peter Bleed to Donald Crabtree where he wrote to say he had hoped to change some terminology in a paper, but was unable to. He hoped the addition still made sense and showed the typological approach.
subject: personal correspondence; article; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter with attached envelope from Harriet Blitzer who introduced herself as a graduate student at Indiana University studying Aegean prehistory, and she had begun her dissertation on stone tools in Greece. There is little research done on stone working in Greece, and to properly do her research, she needs understand the manufacturing process of creating those artifacts. She asked if Crabtree would be willing to work with her for a day or two to show her the process and answer her questions.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; typewritten; travel; envelope
associated_names: Jacobsen, T. W.
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer to confirm that he would be able to meet with and work with her on the dates she suggested. He gave her directions on how to fly in and where she could stay, then requested that she bring any artifacts she could.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; typewritten; travel
associated_names: Statham, Bill
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree. She wrote back to thank him for offering to meet with her, but against all her best attempts, she wasn't able to travel to Idaho due to weather and the holiday. She asked if he would be willing to meet with her at the end of March instead, and she said the extra time would allow her to narrow down her questions and have more photos and drawings of the collection made up, along with physicals from the collection.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; typewritten; travel
associated_names: Braidwood, Robert
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer where he expressed he was disappointed that her expected travel times in December would not work, but he said that she was welcome to come at the end of March. He suggested that if she had the free time however, to apply for the flintknapping school held in June. He gave her details on the school itself and how to apply, and told her that either choice she made he would be home and willing to work with her.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; field school; typewritten; travel
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter. Harriet Blitzer wrote back to Crabtree to thank him for his understanding in their previously cancelled plans and said that she would love to attend the field school over the summer. She said she sent in her application with all the required documents to Earl Swanson already, but if she wasn't accepted she would still like to meet with him in March.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; field school; typewritten; travel
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter. Crabtree wrote to Harriet Blitzer to inform her that it looked likely that her application for the flintknapping field school would be accepted and that she should plan to travel then rather than in March.
subject: professional correspondence; lithics; flintknapping; field school; typewritten; travel
associated_names: Swanson, Earl
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree where she attached a drawing of some blades found in Çayönü, Turkey which were made of obsidian and drawn to scale. She said the Braidwoods wanted to know if they could have been made by indirect percussion. She said that her work on the Greek archaeological record is coming along greatly and that she is setting aside certain pieces to show him next she sees him.
subject: professional correspondence; obsidian; artifact analysis; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer where he said it was possible the blades were made through pressure flaking, but it was more likely from sharpening, and said that the blade had been exposed to extreme heat. He talked about seeing the Braidwoods the next year and her research.
subject: professional correspondence; artifact analysis; travel; research; typewritten
associated_names: Tixier, Jacques; Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter. Blitzer wrote to Crabtree to ask for a recommendation from him for a grant she was applying for as she prepared to write her dissertation. She wanted to spend the year writing it in Greece.
subject: professional correspondence; letter of recommendation; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Postcard addressed to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bill
