associated_names: Binford, Sally
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree where she wrote to offer her condolences regarding the death of Earl Swanson. She said her time at the lithics field school taught her a lot and she often thinks of Don and Earl. She gave some details on her work in Greece and the differences in material and manufacturing that she has noticed, then gave regards from the Braidwoods and wished him well.
subject: personal correspondence; Earl Swanson; research; typewritten
associated_names: Swanson, Earl; Braidwood; Ruthann
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree where she wrote to say that she was glad that he sounded better over the phone than she anticipated and that she was glad his surgery went well. She said many people ask about him and that she envies his bright outlook on everything. She promised to keep him updated on her work on the Aegean collection.
subject: personal correspondence; surgery; health; research; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood; Bordaz
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree where she wrote to him to say it was nice to talk to him on the phone recently and that she would pray for him for his upcoming surgery. She hoped he recovered well and would soon be able to visit the Oriental Institute and visit with the Braidwoods. She said she was nearly done with her dissertation and had spent the summer trying to replicate some of the blades she had studied while in Greece and she attached some drawings of the blades and explained the differences in pressure blades and the platforms they made compared to what she learned at the field school.
subject: personal correspondence; surgery; health; research; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Harriet Blitzer where he wrote back to her to give her information on the drawings she had sent and talked about her time in the field school.
subject: professional correspondence; techniques; typewritten
associated_names: Heizer, Robert; Tixier, Jacques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer where she wrote to thank Crabtree for his discussion of drawings she had previously sent and hoped he had spent time with friends and family over the holidays. She also hoped his surgery went well and that his recovery was easy. She said she had gone to AIA meetings in New York and saw Jacques Tixier and Louise Bordaz there.
subject: personal correspondence; surgery; health; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood; Tixier, Jacques; Bordaz, Louise
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer. She wrote to Crabtree to say she was finishing up her dissertation. She said she had written to him while in Greece but wasn't sure if he got the letters, so gave a brief summary of her time there. She studied in Crete, and now was back and set to teach at the University of Minnesota.
subject: personal correspondence; research; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Postcard to Donald Crabtree from Harriet Blitzer
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter on a postcard from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree to thank him for calling and was glad he was feeling better. She said she was teaching at the University that quarter and maybe the next, but she hoped to be in Greece for the summer. She said the Braidwoods were still working on Jarmo, and they planned to go to Turkey all together that November.
subject: personal correspondence; health; postcard; travel
associated_names: Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Postcard to Donald Crabtree from Harriet Blitzer
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter on the back of a postcard from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree. She wrote to him to give him her new address in New York State and to wish him good health.
subject: personal correspondence; postcard; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to check in with him again since their last phone call. She said the project Crabtree was connected to sounded interesting, then congratulated him on his Ph.D. News, which she heard from the Braidwoods. She and her husband were going to Greece that summer to work on a Bronze Age Site there.
subject: personal correspondence; ph.D.; research; typewritten
associated_names: Braidwood
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Handwritten letter from Harriet Blitzer. She wrote to Crabtree to thank him for the “privilege of studying with” him. She hoped she could live up to the effort he put into the school. She also promised to send him artifacts from Greece.
subject: personal correspondence; tool exchange; handwritten; field school
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Edwin Beauchamp
creator: Beauchamp, Edwin K.
description: Typewritten letter from Edwin Beauchamp at Sandia Laboratories who was studying different flintknapping and flaking techniques. He asked a variety of questions regarding heat treatment, sourcing flint, and measuring fracture toughness. They wanted to produce glass ceramics through heating and flaking and thought studying the process with flint would help understand it.
subject: professional correspondence; flaking; heat treatment; techniques; flint; sourcing; glass; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree
creator: Blitzer, Harriet
description: Typewritten letter from Harriet Blitzer to Donald Crabtree. She wrote to wish him well and say that she was back in Minnesota for a few months before she returns to Greece and Turkey. She sent him some publications she thought he would enjoy from the MASCA Newsletter, one of which was about heat treatment.
subject: personal correspondence; newsletter; heat treatment; typewritten; travel
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Fred Bollinger
creator: Bollinger, Fred
description: Handwritten letter from Fred Bollinger to Donald Crabtree to discuss his experiences of flintknapping with only one hand. He gave some information on what he had success with and asked if Crabtree wanted to trade a few pieces. He attached a colored photo of various pieces he worked on over the years and there is also an envelope attached.
subject: personal correspondence; flintknapping; lithics; tool exchange; photographs; envelope; handwritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob
description: Typewritten letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree to inform Crabtree that he finished his Ph. D. program and started giving a series on lithic technology at the National Museum of Man. He was planning to set up an experimental laboratory program at the University of Maine, Orono the next fall. He was going to chair a session on experimental lithic technology at the annual University of Calgary Department of Archaeology conference. He invited Crabtree to attend as a discussant to evaluate participants’ statements and he attached an outline of the session plans and hoped Crabtree would accept.
subject: personal correspondence; conferences; lecture series; typewritten
associated_names: Dave Sanger
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Jacques Tixier to Rob Bonnichsen forwarded to Donald Crabtree
creator: Tixier, Jacques
description: Typewritten letter from Jacques Tixier to Rob Bonnichsen forwarded to Donald Crabtree which was translated from French using Google Translate. He accepted Bonnichsen's invitation and said he would submit the title of his paper at a later date. He said he was delighted to go to Canada and see Crabtree. On the bottom of the paper there is a note from Bonnichsen to Crabtree saying he thought this letter would be of interest to Crabtree
subject: professional correspondence; forwarded correspondence; typewritten
associated_names: Crabtree, Donald
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Copy of a typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen to congratulate Bonnichsen on his new position with Dave Sanger. He then said that he had busy but productive summer and had practiced new techniques during that time. He had some questions about the conference being held in Calgary, and depending on Bonnichsen's answers he would confirm or deny his acceptance, and then he asked if Tixier and Francois Bordes would be in attendance. He also thanked him for a copy of Jacques Tixier's letter, but said he could not read French.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; typewritten
associated_names: Dave Sanger; Tixier, Jacques; Bordes, Francois; Denise
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob
description: Typewritten letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree to say he was pleased that he was interested in attending the conference and gave him some information on the session and who would be in attendance. He discussed travel grant funding and when the papers would be sent out to everyone.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Tixier, Jacques; Denise
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Telegram from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob

subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob
description: Typewritten letter from Rob Bonnichsen. He wrote to Crabtree to inform him that the Canada Council Travel Grant had been approved and would be distributed to discussants and participants. He said they would be able to reimburse him for 60% of his travel costs, but only after the conference.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; experimental archaeology; travel
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.

subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Tixier, Jacques
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob
description: Typewritten letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree to say it was a pleasure to see Don and Evelyn at the conference the week before and how happy he was with how it turned out. He enclosed a copy of Crabtree’s paper, which he was going to submit for publication to the University of Calgary Monograph Series. He said it would take a couple weeks for reimbursement of travel expenses, then said that he would likely get funding for a closed shop session in Orono, Maine the next fall.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Crabtree, Evelyn
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen to inform Bonnichsen that they had yet to receive reimbursement for travel expenses. He also asked for a copy of the paper he wrote so he could send it to Calgary for publishing. He congratulated Bonnichsen on the success of the conference and session, then said that he was visited by Tsugio from the National Museum of Japan when they returned home, who he worked with for several days.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; typewritten
associated_names: Ruthann; Tsugio
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree
creator: Bonnichsen, Rob
description: Typewritten letter from Rob Bonnichsen to Donald Crabtree where he apologized for the delay in reimbursement and said that he had requested $200 from the Canada Council Travel Grant for him. He said that if he doesn't receive it in the next month to let him know and Bonnichsen would take it a step further. He also said there were good chances of raising funds to have a small group of flintknappers in Orono, Maine the next fall, and he promised to keep Crabtree updated.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; lecture series; travel; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Rob Bonnichsen where he wrote to tell Rob that he had yet to receive his reimbursement payment for the conference and said that he needs to know about it soon since he planned to file his tax return and needed to know if he should deduct the expense or not. He said that he (as well as Francois Bordes) had run into this problem before and it makes them not want to accept invitations unless payment is sent in advance. He said that unless payment was handled differently for the upcoming meeting that Bonnichsen was planning for the fall he would not be willing to make such an expensive trip.
subject: professional correspondence; conferences; travel; meetings; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Edward Boss to Donald Crabtree
creator: Boss, Edward
description: Typewritten letter from Edward Boss to Donald Crabtree. He wrote to request a letter from Crabtree to be published in the upcoming P. I. A. Newsletter in support of American pebble tools. He said many people don't believe that pebble tools exist or can be found in America and wanted to find professionals who agree they exist.
subject: professional correspondence; publications (documents); article; stone tools; typewritten
associated_names: Wormington
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Edward Boss
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree to Edward Boss. He said that the Lively collection showed patterns not seen anywhere else in the New World technology. He said the tools to make the artifacts in the collection could be an important key in American Archaeology and the pebble tools needed to be researched more to know if they were a unique tool or simply a stage in the evolution of tool technology.
subject: professional correspondence; article; publications (documents); stone tools; typewritten
associated_names: Lorenzo; Bordes
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Edward Boss to Donald Crabtree
creator: Boss, Edward
description: Typewritten letter from Edward Boss to Donald Crabtree. He thanked him for his letter in support of pebble tools but said that there were so many responses that it wouldn't be published in the next newsletter, but asked if it could be published in the one after that. He also suggested Crabtree keep an eye out in case anyone found pebble tools in situ before the next deadline so he could update his statement.
subject: professional correspondence; article; publications (documents); stone tools; typewritten
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Edward Boss
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Typewritten letter from Donald Crabtree where he thanked Boss for his last letter regarding the Lively collection, but he needed to clear up that his intention with the letter was not to authenticate pebble tools. He and others have all examined the tools in person and agree that they are man made but they need to be further researched before they can be assigned as a whole new category of tools.
subject: professional correspondence; article; publications (documents); stone tools; typewritten
associated_names: Bordes, Francois; Clark, J Desmond
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Edward Boss to Donald Crabtree
creator: Boss, Edward
description: Typewritten letter from Edward Boss where he wrote back to apologize for his previous assumption and said he was overzealous, and assured Crabtree that the letter would be published with his exact wording. He suggested he make edits if he felt it necessary, then attached Crabtree's original statement. He said a few words were changed for flow and he requested permission to publish this version, or to have Crabtree send a new one.
subject: professional correspondence; article; publications (documents); stone tools; typewritten

title: Letter from Don and Evelyn Crabtree to Alan Bryan and Ruth Gruhn including analysis of Wilson Butte artefacts
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.; Crabtree, Evelyn
description: Letter from Don and Evelyn Crabtree to Alan Bryan and Ruth Gruhn regarding recent happenings and analysis by Don Crabtree of Wilson Butte artifacts. Includes descriptions and theory on artifacts A 11830 (bifacial artifact of fine grained, dark-colored basalt), B 11388 (blade knife/dual edged cutting implement of mottled grey chalcedony), C 10601 (flake of black ignimbrite with interesting features), and D 11523 (fragment of limb bone with break).
subject: stone tools; flintknapping
associated_names: Bryan, Alan; Bryan, Ruth; Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.; Crabtree, Evelyn
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Ruth Gruhn to Don Crabtree including A Technological Description of Artifacts in Assemblage I, Wilson Butte Cave, Idaho by Don Crabtree
creator: Gruhn, Ruth
description: Letter from Ruth Gruhn to Don Crabtree regarding his analysis on the Wilson Butte artifacts; his observations have been edited to a formal paper: A Technological Description of Artifacts in Assemblage I, Wilson Butte Cave, Idaho by Don Crabtree. Abstract: A detailed technical analysis of four artifacts of Assemblage I of Wilson Butte Cave is presented. The artifacts described are a small biface, a true blade, a flake showing evidence of a burin technique, and a modified fragment of bone. The assemblage is in association with a radiocarbon date of 12,550 BC +- 500 years.
subject: stone tools; flintknapping; American Antiquity; conferences
associated_names: Bryan, Alan; Bryan, Ruth; Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.; Crabtree, Evelyn; Bonnichsen, Rob
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter from Donald Crabtree to Herbert De Staebler

He extends the offer of acting as a panel discussionist instead of presenting a paper if Crabtree chooses.

title: Letter between Donald Crabtree and Rae

title: Letter between Donald Crabtree and Mary Evins
creator: Evins, Mary
description: Letter to Donald Crabtree discussing how Evins misses field school and is thankful for Crabtree's work. Evins hopes that Crabtree can come to University of Chicago to teach more flintknapping, and states she is going to Ann Arbor for research. Includes the envelope the letter came in.

title: Letter between Donald Crabtree and J. Allen Eichenberger
creator: Eichenberger, J. Allen
description: Letter to Donald Crabtree discussing Missouri House Bill 787 which would make replication of archaeological specimens illegal in some fields. Eichenberger asks Crabtree if he would express his view to Henry Hamilton who is reviewing the bill. Includes a copy of the house bill.

source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

title: Letter between Donald Crabtree and J Allen Eichenberger
creator: Crabtree, Donald "Don" E.
description: Letter to J. Allen Eichenberger discussing his opposition to Missouri House bill 787 banning replication of archaeological materials. Crabtree argues flintknapping and casting are arts and should thus be allowed. Experimental archaeology is the only way to truly understand lithic technology.
subject: house bill; lithic replication; experimental archaeology; lithic technology; flintknapping; professional correspondence
associated_names: Wormington, Marie
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho

description: A set of articles entitled "Notes on Experiments in Flinknapping: 3 - The Flintknapper's Raw Materials" and "Archaeological Evidence of Acculturation Along the Oregon Trail" by Don Crabtree, and another titled "The Corbiac Blade Technique and Other Experiments" by both Don Crabtree and Francois Bordes. The first article is preceeded by illustrations and diagrams of lithic implements, and includes various flintknapping tools. The second contains images of lithic artifacts found near the Oregon Trail. The third includes diagrams of cores and blademaking. They were published in Volume 12 of "Tebiwa" in 1969.

title: Five people sitting together inside [01]

subject: flintknapping; experimental archaeology; lithic technology; stone tools
source: Donald E. Crabtree Lithic Technology Collection, Alfred W. Bowers Laboratory of Anthropology, University of Idaho
